commit.message:
Add runner to wait until snapshot has been created (#1047)

For snapshot creation (and metrics) so far we've relied only on the
`create-snapshot` runner with a blocking call.

In this commit we are introducing a new runner
`wait-for-snapshot-create`to complement `create-snapshot`. This is
similar to `restore-snapshot` and `wait-for-recovery` and helps in cases
 where network connections maybe terminated making a blocking call
 unsuitable.

verification.payload:
tree b94f18f190ff782a4d6fa65e66cf50895cded9db
parent 77ec10b5e9bf0a710931ae29368dee97729bc8d9
author Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com> 1597412230 +0300
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1597412230 +0300

Add runner to wait until snapshot has been created (#1047)

For snapshot creation (and metrics) so far we've relied only on the
`create-snapshot` runner with a blocking call.

In this commit we are introducing a new runner
`wait-for-snapshot-create`to complement `create-snapshot`. This is
similar to `restore-snapshot` and `wait-for-recovery` and helps in cases
 where network connections maybe terminated making a blocking call
 unsuitable.

commit.message:
Upgrade Elasticsearch client library to 7.8 (#1031)

With this commit we upgrade the Elasticsearch client library to version
7.8. This version also includes a completely rewritten implementation of
the async client that is now bundled with the main client (instead of a
separate library). This allowed us to remove several workaround that we
had to implement before.

Closes #1017

verification.payload:
tree 89ad9507aca0cc86a475b26a5e708328731063b6
parent 6529da75382850fe4ea7fb1dd6a23c2d2ce869bf
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1597309634 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1597309634 +0200

Upgrade Elasticsearch client library to 7.8 (#1031)

With this commit we upgrade the Elasticsearch client library to version
7.8. This version also includes a completely rewritten implementation of
the async client that is now bundled with the main client (instead of a
separate library). This allowed us to remove several workaround that we
had to implement before.

Closes #1017

commit.message:
Show processing time also in comparison reports (#1045)

In #935 we added a new metric `processing time` to the command line
report that can be used to determine Rally's internal overhead. While
the regular command line report shows this metric if configured in
`rally.ini`, the comparison report did not. With this commit we also
show `processing time` in the comparison report as well.

Relates #935

verification.payload:
tree c6debb18651cff9a7c9574f03ab1f2c18dbe09e5
parent 239af9401b3dc201972c54a1455b17fcfdbc539d
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1597296439 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1597296439 +0200

In #935 we added a new metric `processing time` to the command line
report that can be used to determine Rally's internal overhead. While

commit.message: Continue in 2.0.2.dev0
Bump version to 2.0.1
Update changelog for Rally release 2.0.1

Increase acceptable test in time unit tests

The acceptable delta is too narrow, compared to wait period. Increase to
 x3 to avoid noise in environments (like VirtualBox vms) where the clock
  is affected by CPU load.

Installation and offline dist improvements (#1043)

Improve error message during offline installation, if Python3 or pip3
are missing.

Also due to native dependencies, make the offline package Linux specific
 adding the necessary checks.

Finally, update the installation instructions to use Python3 best
practices.

Relates #1032
Closes #1034

verification.payload:
tree c940fb6669250bde236999ae45d22fc9c030369c
parent 016d547ba1d66abb2670020129d130728b2e0add
author Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com> 1596454212 +0300
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1596454212 +0300

Installation and offline dist improvements (#1043)

Improve error message during offline installation, if Python3 or pip3
are missing.

Also due to native dependencies, make the offline package Linux specific
 adding the necessary checks.

Finally, update the installation instructions to use Python3 best
practices.

Relates #1032
Closes #1034

commit.message:
Improve support for benchmarks with many clients (#1044)

With this commit we emit some log messages only once per task (instead
of once per simulated client). These messages were completely repetitive
and also sent at almost the same time. As each log message is sent as an
actor system message to thespian's logging actor, this causes a storm of
messages to be sent which fills up its internal message queue and leads
to dropped messages.

We also increase the size of Rally's internal queue that stores
measurement samples from 2^16 to 2^20 and make this setting configurable
via Rally's configuration file. This allows Rally to buffer more
measurement samples if a lot of clients are configured for a benchmark.

verification.payload:
tree 9ea1ccf3763e5191ba8e12c7ab7c38a203f32ec7
parent 3abeff01eaa3ae3fd2dacfc9cf0e9657cb61470c
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1596191594 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1596191594 +0200

Improve support for benchmarks with many clients (#1044)

With this commit we emit some log messages only once per task (instead
of once per simulated client). These messages were completely repetitive
and also sent at almost the same time. As each log message is sent as an
actor system message to thespian's logging actor, this causes a storm of
messages to be sent which fills up its internal message queue and leads
to dropped messages.

We also increase the size of Rally's internal queue that stores
measurement samples from 2^16 to 2^20 and make this setting configurable
via Rally's configuration file. This allows Rally to buffer more
measurement samples if a lot of clients are configured for a benchmark.

commit.message:
Improve Python 3.8 compatibility (#1030)

With this commit we upgrade two third-party libraries (py-cpuinfo and
tabulate) that produce the following deprecation warnings:

```
.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:415
  .venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:415: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \[
    _invisible_codes_bytes = re.compile(b"\x1b\[\d+[;\d]*m|\x1b\[\d*\;\d*\;\d*m")  # ANSI color codes

.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:977
  .venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:977: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \e
    """Format a fixed width table for pretty printing.

.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py:492
  .venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py:492: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \d
    if re.match('^i\d86$|^x86$|^x86_32$|^i86pc$|^ia32$|^ia-32$|^bepc$', raw_arch_string):
```

verification.payload:
tree effeb8970fd80f4aa185f93ec3fedad752d78fdd
parent cfe42ea756d09c978246d13066e2287771edd940
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1595912148 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1595912148 +0200

```
  .venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:415: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \[
    _invisible_codes_bytes = re.compile(b"\x1b\[\d+[;\d]*m|\x1b\[\d*\;\d*\;\d*m")  # ANSI color codes

.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:977
  .venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tabulate.py:977: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \e
    """Format a fixed width table for pretty printing.

.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py:492

```

commit.message:
Fetch artifact revision lazily on build (#1028)

With this commit we avoid touching the source repository when a specific
git revision is provided for an artifact (with `--revision`) and the
artifact is already present in the source artifact cache. This helps in
situations where an external process has put artifacts into Rally's
source artifact cache from a fork (in which case the artifact revision
will not be present in the main repo and the resolution would fail).

verification.payload:
tree e3489ca6a13e934feb9ea7ea2265fcd496f8acb5
parent 56cab7919508b7f4e11d07290da446f9feffae1d
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1595312959 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1595312959 +0200

Fetch artifact revision lazily on build (#1028)

With this commit we avoid touching the source repository when a specific

artifact is already present in the source artifact cache. This helps in

source artifact cache from a fork (in which case the artifact revision
will not be present in the main repo and the resolution would fail).

commit.message:
Resolve JAVA_HOME for source builds lazily (#1027)

With this commit we resolve JAVA_HOME lazily when attempting to build
Elasticsearch. When a source build is externally provided to Rally's
source artifact cache, there is no need to actually build it. However,
if the target system does not have any JDK installed and we attempt to
install Elasticsearch, the build subsystem is eagerly initialized
(despite the artifact being already cached) and is complaining that it
cannot find a JDK to build the artifact. By lazily resolving JAVA_HOME
we avoid that error.

verification.payload:
tree 0d5be57ae53b40972bad70fba746026a3ea82a3d
parent b59bc099465b86b4d643bc999b85e982fae14d12
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1595224803 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1595224803 +0200

Resolve JAVA_HOME for source builds lazily (#1027)

With this commit we resolve JAVA_HOME lazily when attempting to build
Elasticsearch. When a source build is externally provided to Rally's
source artifact cache, there is no need to actually build it. However,
if the target system does not have any JDK installed and we attempt to
install Elasticsearch, the build subsystem is eagerly initialized
(despite the artifact being already cached) and is complaining that it
cannot find a JDK to build the artifact. By lazily resolving JAVA_HOME
we avoid that error.

commit.message:
Allow runners to determine throughput (#1024)

With this commit Rally recognizes a new response metadata property
`throughput` from runners. When it is present, it will be used as is for
creating throughput samples. The following restrictions apply:

1. The runner must only be executed by one client. This is needed
because throughput is calculated across all clients but in this case
throughput samples are created without any further aggregation.
2. The runner should be rate-limited to avoid that too many throughput
samples are created. When throughput is calculated, all responses are
bucketed into one second buckets but when the calculation is overridden,
each sample also results in one throughput sample.

We also change the existing `IndicesRecovery` runner to use the new
property in order to calculate throughput directly.

verification.payload:
tree 81ca0b5c321bf734c8bffc57ab1d4c3486f1bd38
parent 05bdd48c43ace8f0202e49b50f0973d76c9c0b37
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1594632964 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1594632964 +0200

Allow runners to determine throughput (#1024)

With this commit Rally recognizes a new response metadata property
`throughput` from runners. When it is present, it will be used as is for
creating throughput samples. The following restrictions apply:

1. The runner must only be executed by one client. This is needed
because throughput is calculated across all clients but in this case
throughput samples are created without any further aggregation.
2. The runner should be rate-limited to avoid that too many throughput
samples are created. When throughput is calculated, all responses are
bucketed into one second buckets but when the calculation is overridden,
each sample also results in one throughput sample.

We also change the existing `IndicesRecovery` runner to use the new
property in order to calculate throughput directly.

commit.message:
Add timestamps as meta-info in index recovery (#1019)

With this commit we include the start and stop timestamp as meta-info in
the index recovery runner. This can be useful to correlate the
timestamps to additional diagnostic data (e.g. GC logs or system
metrics).

verification.payload:
tree 3452970d2106d9c322322fb0f2090c84b9e163f7
parent fadc0650ab6b819a4623737d89fff1e6657ced3a
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1592395370 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1592395370 +0200

Add timestamps as meta-info in index recovery (#1019)

With this commit we include the start and stop timestamp as meta-info in
the index recovery runner. This can be useful to correlate the
timestamps to additional diagnostic data (e.g. GC logs or system
metrics).

commit.message:
Check for recovery details when finished (#1018)

With this commit we defer checking any details about indices recovery
until recovery has finished. This avoids any issues with properties that
are not yet returned by the API in earlier stages (e.g.
`stop_time_in_millis`).

verification.payload:
tree 7c0419c906e73401edd9393200f9398cec7d2247
parent 9f73d5d8c1f58d2e247634cfbc3eff5ee91a3750
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1592225542 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1592225542 +0200

Check for recovery details when finished (#1018)

With this commit we defer checking any details about indices recovery
until recovery has finished. This avoids any issues with properties that
are not yet returned by the API in earlier stages (e.g.
`stop_time_in_millis`).

commit.message:
Allow to measure create/restore snapshot speed (#1013)

With this commit we add the ability to measure throughput (in byte/s)
of the create snapshot and restore snapshot operations (the latter is
piggybacked on shard recovery in Elasticsearch). To have Rally report
the actual throughput of the server-side operation, the respective
runners don't take the response time of Elasticsearch into account but
rather how long the operation actually took. We also provide additional
meta-data how many bytes have been snapshotted / recovered. All this
let's us calculate the throughput in byte/s which is more meaningful
than the actual response time of the request.

verification.payload:
tree 11df0fe8a1a679756ca15aaffdf7f6a3f942ecf1
parent 6961f87a20e9927cd0c442c13e99b52a4179ba8b
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1592199713 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1592199713 +0200

Allow to measure create/restore snapshot speed (#1013)

With this commit we add the ability to measure throughput (in byte/s)
of the create snapshot and restore snapshot operations (the latter is
piggybacked on shard recovery in Elasticsearch). To have Rally report
the actual throughput of the server-side operation, the respective
runners don't take the response time of Elasticsearch into account but
rather how long the operation actually took. We also provide additional
meta-data how many bytes have been snapshotted / recovered. All this
let's us calculate the throughput in byte/s which is more meaningful
than the actual response time of the request.

commit.message:
Allow to forcefully close SSL connections (#1016)

With this commit we expose a new client option `enable_cleanup_closed`
which allows to forcefully close an SSL connection that might not have
been properly closed on the server-side. This avoids potentially leaking
connections.

verification.payload:
tree 4bbfbaa5df70d517619636241b1c0dd4ed6aaf5e
parent 42df7d5ce4d98212517a5f5e969beeb5930b20b6
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1591960327 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1591960327 +0200

Allow to forcefully close SSL connections (#1016)

With this commit we expose a new client option `enable_cleanup_closed`
which allows to forcefully close an SSL connection that might not have
been properly closed on the server-side. This avoids potentially leaking
connections.

commit.message:
Scale connection pool automatically (#1015)

With this commit we scale Rally's connection pool automatically between
(at least) 256 and (at most) the number of simulated clients.
Additionally, we allow users to override this value with the client
option `max_connections`. Previously this value has been initialized to
a constant but very high value.

verification.payload:
tree 3d74f05cd42b0c149f957cba29ece389ee22d467
parent 8d328de2c322a9217fb91627340b125539a6a0d7
author Daniel Mitterdorfer <danielmitterdorfer@users.noreply.github.com> 1591949801 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1591949801 +0200

Scale connection pool automatically (#1015)

With this commit we scale Rally's connection pool automatically between
(at least) 256 and (at most) the number of simulated clients.
Additionally, we allow users to override this value with the client
option `max_connections`. Previously this value has been initialized to
a constant but very high value.
